subclassFeature.name: Circle of Ferocity
entries: The half-elf slinks into the shadows, their body slipping into the body of a tiger – vanishing into the brush, stalking their foe. What was once visible becomes invisible, and the tiger reappears pouncing upon its helpless prey, pushed to the ground.

Some druidic tribes and clans devote themselves to one specific animal; transformation and imitation are paramount to their daily ritual. Such clans are a part of the Circle of Ferocity, a circle of druids that focus on their ability to transform into one specific holy animal, and hone their senses, instinct, and capacity to channel their druidic magic through their animal form.

The circle has six focal animals, the wolf, the bear, the tiger, the eagle, the toad, and the spider. As a member of this circle, you are able to shift into one of these six holy animals, a set of teachings granted to you by your druidic tribe or a gift given to you by a venerable tribe you discovered on your adventures.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Tradition
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Ferocity feature}

When you choose this circle, you can choose one specific wild shape that you learn, and then start to exclusively use. You lose your ability to transform into any other Wild Shapes than this chosen Wild Shape, unless they are of CR 1/4 or lower. The chosen Wild Shape can be of one beast from the following list below.

rows: You choose the hunter, the Wolf.
You choose the guardian, the Bear.
You choose the stalker, the Tiger.
You choose the valkyrie, the Eagle.
You choose the mystic, the Toad.
You choose the assassin, the Spider.

entries.name: Choosing a Different Wild Shape
entries: If a beast you wish to choose is not represented in the list, speak to your DM. Some beasts can fit each of the represented roles; i.e. a Panther may fit the Tiger's role. However, some of the abilities are designed to be quite specific to the animal they represent. If you wish to play a druid whose chosen shape is a Giant Boar, the DM may be able to take the Guardian Bear abilities and replace {@bold Bear Hug} with a more appropriate ability fitting for a boar.

All of the Wild Shapes represented in the list below are beasts of CR 1. It is recommended that if you were to choose a beast other than the ones below, to choose another beast of CR 1, or to ask your DM to adjust a creature's attributes and abilities to fit a CR 1 creature.

When you use your chosen Wild Shape, you can activate it as a bonus action, rather than an action. When you do so, you gain a number of temporary hit points equal to twice your druid level, and you can stay in this Wild Shape for 8 hours, instead of 1 hour. If any of the beast's attacks use a saving throw DC of less than your Spell Save DC, it instead uses that save, and you use your proficiency bonus when determining its bonuses to hit, rather than its proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Ferocity feature}

Your link with your primal grove grants you access to certain spells. When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

entries.caption: Circle of Ferocity Spells
rows: {@spell commune with nature}, {@spell wrath of nature|xge}

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Magic
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Ferocity feature}
You gain a mystical ability you can use while in your chosen Wild Shape by expending your spell slots. Each are specific to the chosen beast and are listed below.
You can expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower when you hit a melee attack to deal an {@dice 1d10} additional damage, plus an additional {@dice 1d10} for every spell slot level above 1st.

You can expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower as an action on your turn. When you do so, a storm of nature's wrath whirls around you for 1 minute. You must make concentration on this ability like you would a spell. Whenever an enemy creature starts its turn within 5 feet of you, they must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC. They take {@dice 1d6} slashing damage from the winds on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one.
For each spell slot level, you expend above 1st, the storm deals an additional {@dice 1d6} damage.

You can expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower as a bonus action on your turn. When you do so, you turn {@condition invisible} until the end of your turn. For each spell slot level you expend above 1st, you gain an additional 10 feet of speed until the end of your turn as well.

You can expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower as an action on your turn to make a ranged weapon attack against a creature within 60 feet. On a hit, the attack deals {@dice 2d6} plus the eagle's Dexterity modifier slashing damage.
For each spell slot level you expend above 1st, you can attack one additional creature within 30 feet, dealing the same amount of damage.

You can expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower as an action on your turn. You spit a cloud of poison at a point within 30 feet, and any creature within 5 feet of the point must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC.

On a failure, the creature takes {@dice 2d8} poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of its turn, ending the effect on itself on a success.
For each spell slot level you expend above 1st, the poison deals an additional {@dice 1d8} damage.

You can choose to forgo the regular poison of your bite when you hit a bite or ambush attack on your turn and choose to expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower instead. When you do so, the creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC. Creatures that are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition automatically succeed on this saving throw.

On a failure, the creature is {@condition stunned} until the end of your next turn. When you expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, this ability begins to deal damage, dealing {@dice 1d8} poison damage for each spell slot level above 1st. On a failed save, the creature takes full damage from this, and on a failed save, it takes half as much damage.

subclassFeature.name: Ferocious Empowerment
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Ferocity feature}
You can enhance your Wild Shape with powerful Druidic magic. While you are in your Wild Shape, you can expend spell slots to improve yourself in the following ways:

items: You can expend a spell slot as a bonus action to gain temporary hit points equal to 5 times the slot's level.

When you hit a creature with an attack, you can expend a spell slot to force it to make a Strength saving throw against your Spell Save DC. On a failed save, the creature is knocked back in a line 10 feet per level of the spell slot you expended.
When you take damage you can use your reaction to expend a spell slot to reduce the incoming damage by {@dice 1d8} per level of the spell slot you expended.

subclassFeature.name: Primeval Spirit
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of Ferocity feature}

You can choose to gain a {@dice 1d6} bonus to the next attack roll you make. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, and then you can't use it again until you complete a long rest.

Additionally, each of the Wild Shapes gain a new attack action they can choose to take instead of their original attack options. In the case where a Wild Shape has the Multiattack feature, the new attack action cannot be used as a part of a Multiattack.
These new attacks are listed on the Primeval Spirit table in the next page.

subclassFeature.name: Ferocious Magics
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of Ferocity feature}
Your attacks in beast form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

Make a melee attack against a creature within 5 feet of you that is {@condition prone}. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 2d6} + the wolf's Strength modifier slashing damage and begins to bleed, if the creature is able to. At the start of each of its turns, it takes {@dice 1d6} damage from blood loss and must make a Constitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC.
On a success, the wound heals, and the creature stops bleeding. A creature can be bleeding from more than one wound, but it recovers from all of them on a successful Constitution save.
If you knock a creature {@condition prone} using your Bite attack, you can make this attack as a bonus action.

Make a melee attack against a creature within 5ft of you. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 2d6} + the bear's Strength modifier damage on a hit and must make a Strength saving throw against your Spell Save DC. On a failure, the creature becomes {@condition restrained} in your arms. You can only restrain one creature in this way, and once you are restraining one, you can only target that creature with your claw attacks.
As an action on its turn, the creature can make a Strength (Athletics) check contested against yours to attempt to escape. On a success, the creature escapes.

Make a melee attack against a creature within 5 feet of you. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 1d8} + the tiger's Strength modifier slashing damage, and its speed is reduced to 15 feet, if it wasn't less than 15 feet already, until the end of the target's next turn. If you knock a creature {@condition prone} using your Claw attack, you can make this attack as a bonus action.

You can create a heavy gust, blowing enemies away in an area. Every creature in a 15-foot-cone must make a Strength saving throw or be pushed 30 feet away. A creature holding onto a heavy object or object affixed to the floor makes this save with advantage.

You can make a ranged weapon attack against a creature within 30 feet using the toad's Strength modifier. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 1d10} + the toad's Strength modifier bludgeoning damage and must succeed on a Strength save against your Spell Save DC or it is also pulled 15 feet towards you. If this moves the creature within 5 feet of you, it becomes {@condition restrained} in your mouth as if you used the bite attack action.

You can make a melee weapon attack against a creature within 5 feet that you are hidden from, if they would have advantage on their next attack, they can use this attack in place of their normal attack. On a hit, the creature suffers {@dice 3d10} + the spider's Dexterity modifier piercing damage, and must make a Constitution saving throw against your Spell Save DC, taking 9 ({@dice 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
If you knock a creature {@condition prone} using your Bite attack, you can make this attack as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Patriarch
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of Ferocity feature}

Your affinity with the beast form you transform into grants your insight into its biology, allowing you to shift into forms that are in perfectly fit condition. Your chosen Wild Shape's attributes change in the following ways:

items: It gains 4 Hit Dice, and its hit points adjust accordingly to this (by an amount equal to the average of the Hit Die + the creature's Constitution modifier multiplied by 4).
Its attacks deal additional damage equal to your Wisdom modifier.

It gains the reaction "Strange Resilience". Whenever you must make a Strength, Dexterity or Constitution saving throw while in your chosen Wild Shape, you can use your reaction to gain a {@dice 1d6} bonus to the roll. You may use this reaction after you roll the save. You may do this a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, regaining any expended uses upon the completion of a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ancestral Magics
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of Ferocity feature}

You become able to use another mystical ability that is specific to the ancestry of your chosen Wild Shape. Each of these abilities require you to expend a 5th-level or higher spell slot, but they do not scale with spell slot level like the bestial magic spell-like abilities do.

As an action while in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher to emit a piercing howl. Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@dice 8d8} thunder damage and is {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn on a failed save, or half as much damage and is not {@condition frightened} on a successful one.

As an action while in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher. When you do so, you begin to channel primal energies through your ursine form, becoming a guardian for your allies.

For 1 minute, you regain {@dice 3d6} hit points at the start of each of your turns, and whenever an ally is attacked within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to force them to attack you instead. You must make Concentration checks to maintain this feature. You can maintain the effects of Primal Guardian and Wrath of the Ancients at the same time, but when you do so, the Concentration checks you make count for both effects, so if you fail the check, both effects fade.
As an action while in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher. When you do so, you mark an enemy you can see for death.

For 1 minute, you deal an additional {@dice 3d6} damage on every attack against the creature. Additionally, you know its location in relation to you during this effect's duration, regardless of whether you can see it or not, providing it is still on the same plane of existence as you. If you kill the creature during this effect, it ends, and you regain 30 hit points. You must make Concentration checks to maintain this effect.
As an action while you are in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher. When you do so, you gain the following abilities for the next hour.

items: You gain the Flyby Feature, which means you don't provoke an opportunity attack when you fly out of an enemy's reach.
You gain advantage on Acrobatics checks made to avoid obstacles while flying.
Your fly speed increases to 100 ft.
You can use your bonus action to impose disadvantage on attack rolls against you while you are in the air, provided that there are no objects or creatures within 10 feet of you in all directions.

entries: As an action while you are in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher and start to exude a billowing vapour from your pores.

Whenever a creature starts their turn within 10 feet of you, they must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, the creature's brain is wracked with pain, they take {@dice 2d10} poison damage and become {@condition incapacitated} until the end of their next turn. You must make Concentration checks to maintain this effect.
As an action while you are in your chosen form, you can expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher. When you do so, you gain the following abilities for the next hour.

items: You have a +10 bonus to Dexterity (Stealth) checks.
You can fire your webbing long ranges to create traversable tightropes across gaps as wide as 120 feet.
Your Web action no longer needs to be recharged.
You can use your reaction to use your Web action whenever a creature moves more than 20 feet away from you.

entries: Additionally, you gain the following action for the duration, which can be used on your turns in combat.

entries.name: Web Spray (Recharge 5-6).
entries: You fire a large gout of webbing at a point within 60 feet. Every creature within 5 feet of the impact point must make a Dexterity saving throw or they become {@condition restrained} by the webbing.

As an action, the restrained target can make a Strength check against your Spell Save DC, bursting the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 10; hp 5; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Strange
entries: Some, though rare and mystifying, druids believe that nature extends to creatures beyond that of just mere beasts. These druids belong to the Circle of the Strange.

Druids of the Circle of the Strange often feel more connection with that of the undead or monsters then they do with more 'traditional' species. These types of druids are as varied as they are abstruse in their beliefs, some believe in the redemption and misrepresentation of 'alternate' creature types, while others may simply find sport in hunting them down and assuming their forms.

subclassFeature.name: Strange Shape
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Strange feature}
You gain the ability to use Wild Shape on your turn as a bonus action, rather than as an action.

Additionally, while you are transformed by Wild Shape, you can use a bonus action to expend a spell slot of 5th level or lower. When you do, the next successful attack you make deals an additional {@dice 1d10} poison or necrotic damage, plus an additional {@dice 1d10} for every spell slot level above 1st.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Strange feature}

Your link with your primal grove grants you access to certain spells. When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

entries.caption: Circle of the Strange Spells
rows: {@spell swarm of decay|WMPS}, {@spell tasha's caustic brew|tce}

subclassFeature.name: Circle Forms
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Strange feature}

The rites of your circle grant you the ability to transform into more 'bizarre' or 'misrepresented' creature types. You can use your Wild Shape to transform into a creature with the Monstrosity creature type with a challenge rating equal to your druid level divided by 4. If this calculation results in a fraction that is greater than, but not equal to one-half, you round up. Or, refer to the table below. You are still restricted by movement limitations as per the normal wild shape table, and all other rules of Wild Shape.
Due to your endless fascination with this creature type, you never got around to studying traditional beasts, and thus cannot wild shape into them.

subclassFeature.name: Strange Empowerment
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Strange feature}
You can enhance your Wild Shape with powerful Druidic magic. While you are in your Wild Shape, you can expend spell slots to improve yourself in the following ways:

items: You can expend a spell slot as a bonus action to gain temporary hit points equal to 5 times the slot's level.

When you hit a creature with an attack, you can expend a spell slot to force it to make a Strength saving throw against your Spell Save DC. On a failed save, the creature is knocked back in a line 10 feet per level of the spell slot you expended.
When you take damage you can use your reaction to expend a spell slot to reduce the incoming damage by {@dice 1d8} per level of the spell slot you expended.

subclassFeature.name: Strange Strikes
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Strange feature}
Your attacks in your monster or undead form count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: The Stranger, The Stronger
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Strange feature}
Your connection with the undead or monster forms you transform into become even stronger. Your chosen Wild Shape's attributes change in the following ways:

items: It gains 4 Hit Dice, and its hit points adjust accordingly to this (by an amount equal to the average of the Hit Die + the creature's Constitution modifier multiplied by 4).
Its attacks deal additional damage equal to your Wisdom modifier.

It gains the reaction "Strange Resilience". Whenever you must make a Strength, Dexterity or Constitution saving throw while in your chosen Wild Shape, you can use your reaction to gain a {@dice 1d6} bonus to the roll. You may use this reaction after you roll the save. You may do this a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, regaining any expended uses upon the completion of a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Strange Symbiosis
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Strange feature}
One trait from one of your wild shapes affects your body, even when not transformed. You can choose one of the following traits:

items: Movement
Senses
Language
Resistances
Immunities
A single attack

entries: If a creature has multiple options from one trait available (I.E. multiple resistances or immunities), you choose only one. If an attack is chosen, it must be something your untransformed body is still capable of doing.

entries.name: For example
entries: Your body may adapt to add poison to your teeth to bite something, but you still cannot swallow something larger than your own body.
While wildshaped in a form that you have not chosen this trait from, it is not available to you until you revert back to your normal form.
You may choose a different trait each day at dawn.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Guardians
entries: While all Druids forge a relationship with the natural world, those who join the Circle of Guardians dedicate their lives to protecting the elder forests and sacred groves that serve as sources of druidic magic. Known simply as Guardians, these Druids are as stalwart and resilient as the trees they defend.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Limbs
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Guardians feature}
The magic of the elder forest you guard empowers your body with primeval power. Your unarmed strikes deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + your Strength modifier on hit.
Moreover, when you hit a creature with an unarmed strike, you can expend a spell slot to cast {@spell ensnaring strike} on your target as part of your unarmed strike attack.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Guardians feature}

Your link with your primal grove grants you access to certain spells. When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Guardian Form
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Guardians feature}

The primordial forests you protect can lend you their elder powers. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of Wild Shape and transform into a treelike Guardian Form, which grants you the following benefits for 10 minutes:

items: Your flesh is covered in bark. Your Armor Class equals 10 + your Constitution modifier + your Wisdom modifier.
As a bonus action, you can grant yourself temporary hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1).
The reach of your unarmed strikes increases by 5 feet.
You can use your Wisdom, in place of Strength, for the attack and damage rolls for your unarmed strikes.

entries: Your Guardian Form transformation ends early if you are reduced to 0 hit points, or you use a bonus action on your turn to revert to your normal form.

subclassFeature.name: Arboreal Strikes
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Guardians feature}

The elder grove you defend enhances your combat abilities. You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your Druid cantrips in place of one of those attacks.
Also, your unarmed strikes count as magic for the sake of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Grasp of the Forest
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Guardians feature}

Your elder magic stimulates wild growth. As an action, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to cast {@spell plant growth}. When you do, you can choose a number of creatures equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) that can ignore the difficult terrain created, as the plants move and allow them to pass by.

subclassFeature.name: Verdant Mastery
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Guardians feature}

Your body is completely suffused with elder druidic magic. When you transform into Guardian Form, you grow by one size category, for example from Medium to Large, and you resemble an ancient treant. You also gain resistance to all bludgeoning, piercing, poison, and slashing damage.

Finally, the duration of your Guardian Form transformation increases to 1 hour, and while you are in Guardian Form, you can speak to plants as if you were under the effects of the {@spell speak with plants} spell, so long as you speak in Druidic.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Harvest
entries: The cyclical nature of life is a central belief of every Druid, no matter their Circle. However, to members of the Circle of the Harvest, this cycle is of utmost importance. They stand as the protectors of natural law and look to destroy any who would violate the cycle of life with necromancy or other dark magic.

subclassFeature.name: Druidic Avenger
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Harvest feature}

You have taken up the ancient mantle of the Druidic Avenger. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape to transform into your Avenger Form. While in this Form, you retain your game statistics, but you gain the benefits below:

items: Your walking speed increases by 10 feet.
So long as you are not wearing medium or heavy armor or wielding a shield, you gain a bonus to your Armor Class equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).
When you make a Constitution saving throw to maintain your concentration, you gain a bonus to your roll equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).

entries: Your Avenger form lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are {@condition incapacitated} or you end it as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Harvest Scythe
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Harvest feature}

Over the course of 1 hour, which can be during a short or long rest, you can perform an ancient ritual to conjure a Harvest Scythe. It is a magic weapon with the finesse and versatile properties and deals {@dice 1d8} ({@dice 1d10}) slashing damage on hit. This Scythe can be used as a spellcasting focus by you, and you gain the following benefits while you wield it:

items: You know {@spell chill touch|WMPS}. It counts as a Druid spell for you, but it doesn't count against your Cantrips Known.
You always have {@spell inflict wounds} prepared. It counts as a Druid spell for you, but it doesn't count against the total number of Druid spells you can prepare each day.

You can cast {@spell inflict wounds} at 1st-level, without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

entries: If you lose your Scythe, you can perform a 1-hour ritual and conjure another, and the previous scythe turns to ash. If you find a magical melee weapon, you can perform a 1-hour ritual to infuse the magical melee weapon's properties into your Harvest Scythe. When you do so, the original magic melee weapon is completely destroyed as it turns into ash.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Harvest feature}
You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn. Moreover, you can cast one of your Druid cantrips in place of one of those attacks.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Defense
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Harvest feature}

You can channel druidic magic to absorb incoming blows. As a reaction when you take damage in your Avenger Form, you can expend a spell slot to reduce the incoming damage by five times the level of the spell slot you expended.

subclassFeature.name: Cull the Unnatural
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Harvest feature}

Your desire to destroy the enemies of nature empowers your attacks. You add your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1) to the damage of any attacks you make with your Harvest Scythe while you are in your Avenger Form.
Finally, your ancient magic grants you resistance to unnatural powers. You gain resistance to necrotic damage when you are in your Avenger Form.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Scales
entries: While most Druids protect places of natural power or wield the forces of nature, some form Circles in service of ancient dragons. In an effort to defend their lair, elder dragons will bestow some of their power upon Druids who maintain its territory. The older the dragon, the larger its Druidic Circle.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Scales feature}

Your elder dragon grants you access to certain spells. When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of Druid spells you can prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of the Elder Dragon
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Scales feature}

When you join this Circle you pledge yourself in service to a great dragon. Choose the scale color of the dragon you serve. You gain resistance to the damage type associated with your elder dragon's Element on the table below.

subclassFeature.name: Draconic Wild Shape
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Scales feature}

The draconic power you have been gifted allows you to adopt more powerful forms. As a bonus action, you can use Wild Shape to transform into a {@filter beast with a Challenge Rating as high as 1|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1]|type=beast|speed type=!fly;!swim|miscellaneous=!swarm}. You can ignore the Max. CR column of the Beast Shapes table, but you must abide by all other limitations.

Also, when you use Wild Shape to transform into a beast, you can expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to empower your transformation with the draconic magic of your Circle, granting your beast form the following additional benefits:

items: The beast is covered in a thin sheen of draconic scales that resemble those of the dragon you serve. The beast's Armor Class is equal to 13 + its Dexterity modifier unless its natural Armor Class was already higher.
The beast gains resistance to the damage type associated with the Element of the elder dragon you serve.
The beast gains temporary hit points equal to five times the level of the spell slot you used to empower this form.
As a bonus action, you can expend a spell slot of 1st-level or higher to grant your beast form temporary hit points equal to five times the level of the spell slot you expend.

entries: Once you empower your Wild Shape in this way you must finish a short or long rest before you can do so again.

subclassFeature.name: Infused Strikes
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of Scales feature}
When you empower your Wild Shape transformation with draconic magic, your beast's natural weapon attacks deal the damage type of your dragon's Element.
In addition, you can now Wild Shape into a beast with a CR as high as your Druid level divided by 3, rounded down.

subclassFeature.name: Terrifying Wild Shape
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of Scales feature}

Your mastery over the draconic magic you wield allows you to take on the form of a true dragon. As a bonus action, you can expend two uses of Wild Shape at the same time to take the form of a {@filter dragon with a CR of 5 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&5]|type=dragon|miscellaneous=!swarm}.
If you Wild Shape into a dragon with a breath weapon, you can choose for its breath weapon to deal the damage type of your elder dragon's Element in place of the normal damage.

subclassFeature.name: Elder Power
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of Scales feature}

You have become one of the most loyal servants of your elder dragon and are given increased power. When you empower your Wild Shape transformation with draconic magic, the beast sprouts a leathery pair of draconic wings and gains a 40-foot flying or swimming speed (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Sower
entries: The Druid Circle that is most revered by civilized peoples is that of the Sowers. Folktales tell of an ancient druidic sage that guided mortals to the discovery of agriculture. Drawing on their mystical knowledge of the natural world, this Druid led ancient peoples to establish the first farms and towns.
Those who join the Circle of the Sower follow the example of that ancient sage. They wander the countryside and offer magical aid to farmers, gardeners, and all who till the soil.

subclassFeature.name: Wandering Sage
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Sower feature}

You gain a mystical understanding of the natural cycle of life, growth, and death. You gain proficiency in Nature. Whenever you make an Intelligence (Nature) check you gain a bonus to your roll equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of +1).

subclassFeature.name: Mystic Harvest
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Sower feature}

When you join this Circle, you learn to use druidic magic to produce wondrous fruits. As a bonus action, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to produce one Mystical Fruit from the list below in your empty hand. The Fruit can be eaten as an action. Any uneaten Fruit spoils after 1 minute.

entries.name: Invigorating Fruit
entries: The creature that eats this Fruit regains hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier + your Druid level. Any hit points over its hit point maximum become temporary hit points.

entries.name: Mystic Fruit
entries: The creature that eats this Fruit regains a single expended spell slot of a level equal to your Wisdom modifier or lower.
Once a creature benefits from this Fruit it must complete a long rest before it can do so again.

entries.name: Revitalizing Fruit
entries: The creature that eats this Fruit is instantly cured of one of the following conditions: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition petrified}, {@condition poisoned}, a reduction to an ability score or its hit point maximum, or its exhaustion level is reduced by 1.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Sower feature}

When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they do not count against the total number of Druid spells you can prepare each day.

entries.caption: Circle of the Sower Spells
rows: {@spell create food and water}, {@spell plant growth}

subclassFeature.name: Wild Growth
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Sower feature}

You cause plants to blossom and thrive wherever you travel. When you take a short or long rest, the effects of the 8-hour casting of {@spell plant growth} immediately take effect in the area around you, unless you choose to withhold them.
Your connection with plant life also grants you immunity to poison damage, the {@condition poisoned} condition, and natural poisons.

subclassFeature.name: Abundant Harvest
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Sower feature}
You can use the magic of your Wild Shape to produce more potent produce. When you produce a Mystic Fruit you can choose from the following additional options:

entries.name: Emboldening Fruit
entries: The next time the creature that eats this Fruit rolls a d20, it can choose to substitute its d20 roll with your Druid level.

entries.name: Primal Fruit
entries: The creature that eats this Fruit is resistant to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage for the next minute.

subclassFeature.name: Verdant Grasp
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Sower feature}

You have an unparalleled command over plant life. You can cast {@spell grasping vine} without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
When you cast {@spell grasping vine}, you can conjure two vines at once in separate locations within range of the spell. You can direct both vines at once with the same bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Swarm
entries: Druids defend every life, no matter how small or unseemly it may be. Some take this call more seriously than others and join a Circle of the Swarm. Often centered around sewers of great settlements or among festering swamps, these Druids have an affinity for vermin with many legs or gnawing teeth.

subclassFeature.name: Swarmcaller
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Swarm feature}

The swarms of pests you defend are never far. You learn the {@spell infestation|xge} cantrip, but it does not count against your total number of Cantrips Known. When you cast {@spell infestation|xge}, you can target two creatures that are within 5 feet of each other, and when a creature fails its saving throw against this spell, you can choose which direction it moves.

Moreover, you can use a bonus action on your turn to use Wild Shape to turn into a {@filter swarm of beasts, such as a swarm of rats|bestiary|type=beast|miscellaneous=swarm}. When you do so, it gains the following benefits:

items: It gains a number of bonus hit points equal to 1 + your Druid level.
It can add your Wisdom modifier to all ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Swarm feature}

When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they do not count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Swarm
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Swarm feature}
You call and the swarm answers. While you are Wild Shaped into a swarm, you can cast {@spell infestation|xge} and your Circle Spells as normal, and their effects manifest as part of your swarm.
Also, your attacks while you are Wild Shaped into a swarm count as magical for the sake of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of the Swarm
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Swarm feature}
Your vermin are always gathering information for you. When you finish a short or long rest, you gain information about the surrounding area as if you had cast {@spell commune with nature}.
When cast in this way, the spell works even where nature has been replaced by construction, such as cities and towns.

subclassFeature.name: From Many, One
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Swarm feature}

You and the multitudes you protect have become one being. When you are reduced to 0 hit points, but are not killed outright, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to turn into a {@filter swarm of beasts with a Challenge Rating of 1/2 or lower|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1/2]|type=beast|miscellaneous=swarm}, and immediately move up to the swarm's walking, flying, or climbing speed without provoking opportunity attacks.
Once you use this feature you must finish a long rest before you can use your Wild Shape in this way again.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Tempest
entries: Drawn to the most destructive forces of the natural world, the Tempest Druids wield the power of storms. They often view themselves as great defenders of nature and use their power to strike back when civilization encroaches upon the wilds. Theirs is the power of lightning, thunder, ice, and wind, and woe to any who stand against these acolytes of destruction.

subclassFeature.name: Servants of the Tempest
entries: While Tempest Domain and Circle of the Tempest are similar mechanically, they almost always serve different masters. Clerics serve gods of storms and destruction, but Tempest Druids are often found in the service of nature itself or ancient elementals.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tempest feature}

When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they do not count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Wrath
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tempest feature}

You can channel the destructive power of nature. When you cast a Druid spell that deals lightning or thunder damage, you can expend a use of Wild Shape and cause it to deal maximum damage to one target, instead of rolling.
You may only use this ability twice per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Tempestuous Rebuke
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tempest feature}

The elemental powers rebuke those who strike at you, their acolyte. When a creature within 5 feet that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to force it to make a Dexterity saving throw. It takes {@dice 2d8} thunder damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful save.
You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all of your expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Thunderous Strike
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Tempest feature}
You carry the fury of the storm. Once per turn, when you hit a Large or smaller creature with a melee attack, you can also push it up to 10 feet away from you in a straight line.

subclassFeature.name: Tempestuous Form
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Tempest feature}
You can use druidic magic to transform into a minor version of the tempest you serve. As an action, you can expend two uses of Wild Shape to transform into an air elemental.

subclassFeature.name: One with the Storm
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Tempest feature}
You have become one with the destructive power of nature. You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed.
In addition, whenever you use Nature's Wrath, the spell deals maximum damage to every target, instead of just one.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Tides
entries: Few natural forces exert as much influence over mortals as the waters of the world. Rain for crops, raging storms, and winding rivers all influence the lives of mortals. Tidal Druids monitor the relationship between civilization and the waters of oceans, rivers, and lakes. They are often found using the innate magic found in the waters to heal the sick, provide rest to the weary, and nurture the crops of common folk.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of the Sea
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tides feature}
Your dedication to primal waters has changed you. When you join this Circle, you gain the ability to breathe both air and water, and you gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tides feature}
Your connection with the primal waters grants you access to certain spells. You learn the {@spell shape water} cantrip, but it does not count against your total number of Cantrips Known.

When you reach certain Druid levels, you gain access to the spells in the table below. They count as Druid spells for you, and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of spells you prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Tidal Aura
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Tides feature}

As a bonus action, you can expend a use of Wild Shape to exude a mystical watery force in a 15-foot radius. Creatures of your choice within this Aura treat it as {@quickref difficult terrain|CDrd|3}. If a creature has a swimming speed it ignores this effect.

Your Tidal Aura also enhances your healing powers. When you cast a spell that restores hit points to a creature within this Tidal Aura, one target within the Aura regains additional hit points equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1).
Your Tidal Aura lasts for 1 minute. Its effects end early if you end it as a bonus action, or if you are {@condition incapacitated}.

subclassFeature.name: Undertow
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Tides feature}

Your Tidal magic has grown in power. When you cast a spell that forces a creature in your Tidal Aura to make a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw, you can empower the spell. Any creature within your Tidal Aura makes their initial saving throw against the empowered spell at disadvantage.
You can empower a spell in this way a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Waters of Life
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Tides feature}

You can wield the magic of primal water to rejuvenate your allies as you hinder your foes. When you activate your Tidal Aura, you gain a pool of temporary hit points equal to your Druid level + your Wisdom modifier that you can distribute to creatures of your choice within your Tidal Aura.
When your Tidal Aura ends, any remaining temporary hit points from this feature are immediately dispelled.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Waves
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Tides feature}
Your bond with the mystical waters has reached its apex. You can cast {@spell control water} at will, without expending a spell slot, so long as you target a body of water of sufficient size.
Also, the radius of your Tidal Aura increases to 30 feet, and creatures of your choice treat the area of your Tidal Aura as difficult terrain even if they have a swimming speed.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Wild Magic
entries: Druids have always been known to be... eccentric. Some of them just take that to a bit more extreme. Whether it is through exposure to extreme elements they have no business living near, or bizarre bio-arcanic experiments, one circle of druids pushes their magic beyond any normal, ordered, or conventional means, and into the realm of Wild Magic.

subclassFeature.name: WILD Shape
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Wild Magic feature}

Wild Magic Druids are so connected to the raw, unbridled, chaos of magic that extends beyond even nature's mysteries, they lose almost all control of their transformations. When they shift, they shift into unpredictable creatures, with unpredictable effects. When a Wild Magic Druid wild shapes, they first roll on the Wild Magic Druid Creature Table. As they level up, they get access to higher level tables, with more powerful creatures on them. If a Wild Magic Druid has access to more than one creature table, they may decide after rolling which table to shift from. Additionally, due to the unpredictability of their nature, a wild shape costs a bonus action, rather than an action.

entries.caption: Wild Magic Druid Wild Magic Effects
rows: You are sized Tiny, regardless of the size of the creature you were meant to wildshape into. You suffer the effects of "Reduce" in the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce} spell.
You are sized one size larger than the creature you are meant to wildshape into, and are under the effects of "Enlarge" in the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce} spell.
You smell like delicious cooked meats. Everyone within a mile, capable of smellling, can smell you.

Tiny magic guardians (you decide their appearance) rise from the earth and protect you. When a creature enters your melee range for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@dice 2d8} [random] damage.

Tiny magic guardians rise from the earth to pester you. You must make a Constitution saving throw against your own spell DC at the beginning of each of your turns to not be distracted. If distracted, you make attacks with disadvantage.
You cannot revert from your wild shape until your HP is reduced to 0.
You become a tiny potted plant. You have all the stats (other than size) of the shape you were meant to wild shape into, but you are still a tiny potted plant.

Every time a creature makes contact with you, that limb turns into the limb of the next closest creature that is of a different race. Their limb still operates the same mechanically. This lasts for 24 hours (unless it's an NPC and the DM decides that it's permanent).

Oops, an extra limb! It is attached to your form in any location you choose. You can replace one attack you make with this limb, which deals {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage, and automatically grapples the target (escape dc equal to spell save dc).
You light up like a disco ball. Beautiful lights rotate and emit from you.

A creature you touch lights up like a beautiful disco ball, until they then touch a different creature. This curse lasts for 30 days. Once you've been afflicted, you cannot be afflicted again until the curse has ended.
You are sized Gargantuan, regardless of the size of the creature you were meant to wildshape into. You do not get any extra benefits, it's just a pain in the ass.
The ground in a 20 foot area around you at the time that you wild-shape becomes *STICKY*. It is now difficult terrain, for all time.
The caster vomits up {@dice 1d6} {@creature swarm of wasps|MM}, but they're bees instead because we hate wasps. On an even number they are friendly, on an odd number they are hostile.

The nearest creature with an intelligence of less than 3 becomes awakened, as per the effects of the spell. It can also grow any features needed to speak verbally. Roll a D20. On an even number they are thankful, on an odd number they resent you.

Your wild-shape appears to fail. You take this turn as if you had not spent the economy to wild shape. At the beginning of your next turn, roll on the Wild Shape Creature table twice more, and choose the shape you'd like. You then transform as a free action.
You accidentally wild-shape your bones before your skin. Rookie mistake! Take {@dice 1d8} piercing damage.
Your bones and skin are unexpectedly infused with a surge of extra magic. Your AC increases by your proficiency bonus. This lasts until you revert from your wild shape.
All beasts are attracted to you for the next 24 hours.

As you wildshape, your body is covered in a sticky substance that hardens before you can react. Your turn ends. You are resistant to all damage until the beginning of your next turn, when the shell cracks and you emerge as the shape you were meant to wild shape into. You regain your highest level expended spell slot, have beautiful wings that grant you a hover speed equal to your walking speed, and are under the effects of the Haste spell.

entries: The inconceivable ways that druids manage to manifest Wild Magic has honed their mental, physical, and spiritual malleability and aids them manifesting the changes of their wild shapes, with effort. By expending a spell slot, and a bonus action, they are able to wild shape into a new form, rolling on a Wild Magic Druid Creature Table they have unlocked and the Wild Magic Druid Wild Magic Effects Table again (even when not currently in a wild shape). The level of the spell slot that must be expended, corresponds to the level of the table the druid wild shapes from, (e.g. a level 1 spell for Creature Table A,  a level 2 spell for Creature Table B, etc.) They can use this ability a number of times equal to their proficiency bonus per long rest.

If your wildshape grants you an ability to possess, swallow, or otherwise do something your un-wild shaped body would be capable of, when your wild shape ends, so does your capacity to continue using that ability.

You now have access to Wild Magic Druid Creature Table B. After rolling your {@dice d20}, choose the corresponding number from any table you have access to. Additionally, your attacks in your wild shape forms count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of Wild Magic feature}

Your connection with the unpredictable has only strengthened your luck. Any time you'd roll on a table, you may roll twice and choose the outcome. Ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws are not part of any tables for the purpose of this ability. Additionally, you may choose both outcomes on the Wild Magic Effects Table. subclassFeature.name: Alternate Circle of the Land
entries: Druids of the Circle of the Land are the most common Druid, if Druids can be considered common at all. These sages of the natural world are able to attune themselves to almost any environment, giving them an increased ability to draw out the natural magic of the flora and fauna that surround them.

subclassFeature.name: Localized Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Land feature}

You have mastered a greater amount of druidic magic. You learn one additional {@filter Druid cantrip|spells|level=0|class=druid} of your choice, but it does not count against your total number of Cantrips Known.

In addition, you are infused with the ability to cast certain spells based on your environment. When you finish a long rest, you can attune to the local environment, choosing the option that best represents your surroundings: arctic, cave, coast, desert, forest, grassland, mountain, or swamp.

While attuned to that environment you gain access to the corresponding spells on the Localized Spells table below. These spells count as Druid spells for you and you always have them prepared, but they don't count against the total number of Druid spells you can prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Recovery
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of the Land feature}

You can regain some of your druidic magic by communing with nature. At the end of a short rest, you can choose to recover a number of expended spell slots with a combined level less than or equal to half your Druid level rounded up. Spell slots you regain must be 5th-level or lower.
Once you use this feature to recover spell slots you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Acolyte of Nature
entries: {@i 6th-level Circle of the Land feature}
You move effortlessly through the wild. You ignore the effects of {@quickref difficult terrain|CDrd|3} imposed by your attuned environment.

Moreover, you have advantage on saving throws to resist the harmful effects of your attuned environment. Examples include extreme temperatures and weather, hostile flora, or other magical environmental effects.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Ward
entries: {@i 10th-level Circle of the Land feature}

You are able to adapt to the hostile effects of nearly any wild place. When you finish a short or long rest, choose one of the following damage types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder. You gain resistance to that type of damage until the end of your next short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Sanctuary
entries: {@i 14th-level Circle of the Land feature}

Creatures of the natural world can sense your devotion to nature and are hesitant to attack you. When a beast or plant attacks you, you can force it to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the attack automatically misses. On a success, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.
Beasts and plants with a Wisdom of 4 or higher are aware of this effect before they make their attack against you.

trait.name: Distracting Swoop
entries: If the lymarien moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be distracted until the end of its next turn. A distracted creature has disadvantage on its next attack roll or ability check.

trait.name: Speak with Beasts
entries: The lymarien can communicate with beasts as if they shared a language.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) slashing damage.
A tiny bird swoops through the air and alights on a nearby branch. It has the body of a tiny hawk, the colorful wings of a butterfly, and the head of an elf with large, luminous eyes.

entries.name: Miniscule Fey
entries: Dwelling in pastoral woods and rich farmland, the lymarien is one of the smallest fey in existence. Barely larger than a wasp, a lymarien is frequently mistaken for a butterfly and often ignored by larger creatures. They are sometimes preyed upon by birds like {@creature owl|mm|owls} and {@creature crow|wdmm|crows}, or attacked by evil fey like {@creature morko|ccodex|morkos} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}).

entries.name: Guardians of the Young
entries: Lymariens have a fondness for fey and animal young, sometimes putting their lives at risk against superior opponents to save such creatures. When faced with a particularly powerful threat, lymariens form into massive, short-lived {@creature lymarien swarm|tob2|swarms}, gaining potent magical abilities in the process.

entries.name: Lymarien Familiars
entries: Some lymarien might choose to serve a good-aligned spellcaster as a familiar. Such lymarien have the following trait.

entries.name: Familiar
entries: The lymarien can serve another creature as a familiar, forming a magic, telepathic bond with that willing companion. While the two are bonded, the companion can sense what the lymarien senses as long as they are within 1 mile of each other. While the lymarien is within 10 feet of its companion, the companion shares the lymarien's Speak with Beasts trait. At any time and for any reason, the lymarien can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

While the lymarien is within 10 feet of its companion, the companion shares the lymarien's Speak with Beasts trait. At any time and for any reason, the lymarien can end its service as a familiar, ending the telepathic bond.

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: The alliumite has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks it makes in any terrain with ample obscuring plant life.

trait.name: Tearful Stench
entries: Each creature other than an alliumite within 5 feet of the alliumite when it takes damage must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the start of the creature's next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the Tearful Stench of all alliumites for 1 minute.

action.name: Thorn Dart
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Grass Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

{@i An ambulatory plant half the size of a halfling slashes out with its grass blades. Its peeling skin, its hair of sprouts, and its svelte, nimble physique allude to its fey origins. The odor of onions and garlic wafts from it as it advances..}

Stepping on a patch of wild onions, garlic, or leeks in the woods can prove to be a deadly affair. The onion folk are easily riled, and, once angry, they attack relentlessly, slashing at ankles with their wicked grass blades.

entries.name: Fey Origins
entries: Alliumites began as a patch of sweet onions in a forest thicket, raised to sentience when a great deal of pixie dust spilled upon them. Arms and legs sprouted from their forms, and they began to think for themselves. Now they seek only to propagate, spreading far and wide. They have developed vast colonies through underground tunnels beneath forests and fields.

entries.name: Nature's Gardeners
entries: Alliumites feel a supernatural compulsion to plant chives, garlic, and other wild herbs wherever they go. This instinctive imperative makes them well-suited as gardeners. Though their wild gardens might look haphazard to the untrained eye, an alliumite knows exactly where each individual seed and sprout is planted. Woodland animals and benevolent fey creatures can find sustenance and shelter in these plant sanctuaries, but woe to those who threaten or damage anything planted within an alliumite garden.

entries.name: Capable Combatants
entries: Alliumites are exceptionally nimble. With razor-edged grass scimitars and darts made of thorns, they can overwhelm even a well-prepared adventurer. Able to dig through the ground almost as easily as walk and with a penchant for hidden and quiet movement, an alliumite can sneak up on anyone. If one of the onion folk is harmed in battle, it releases a stench that can make eyes water and temporarily cause blindness. Some say the stench can be so powerful as to even induce retching.

trait.name: Adhesive
entries: The boot grabber adheres to anything that touches it. A Large or smaller creature adhered to the boot grabber is also {@condition grappled} by it (escape {@dc 13}). Ability checks made to escape this grapple have disadvantage.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The boot grabber can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the boot grabber remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a dirty puddle of water.

action.name: Adhesive Hands
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage and the target is subjected to its Adhesive trait. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the boot grabber can't make adhesive hands attacks against other targets.

action.name: Unearthly Hum
entries: The boot grabber targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. It emits a high frequency humming noise which can only be heard by the target. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or move toward the boot grabber on its turn by the shortest and most direct route, ending its turn when it comes within 5 feet of the boot grabber.
{@i A pair of powerful hands made from a weird transparent substance springs forth from the puddle lying on the cavern floor.}
Boot grabbers are ooze-like aberrant creatures that lie in wait for approaching prey on the floors of dank dungeons, overgrown ruins, and dark caverns.

entries.name: Deadly Ambushers
entries: Its transparent, amorphous body means a boot grabber is easily mistaken for a puddle or patch of wet rock, allowing the creature to strike with surprise and grab hold of its victim's legs or feet with its strong hand-shaped appendages. The boot grabber can lure a creature that is reluctant to approach by emitting an unearthly, high-frequency sound. Once it has seized its target, the boot grabber secretes a strong adhesive to stop the hapless creature from pulling free and continues to crush its foe's lower limbs. When the victim finally ceases struggling, the boot grabber flows over the helpless victim's body to start consuming it.

entries.name: Creations of Warped Sorcery
entries: Boot grabbers are believed to have been created centuries ago in twisted experiments conducted by deranged arcanists seeking new weapons to use against their rivals. Willing to wield fell sorceries that tapped into the alien power of the Void, these mages carried out all manner of blasphemous research. By melding alien protoplasm harvested from {@creature Shoggoth|ToB|shoggoths} ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}) with the dismembered bodies of human captives from a rival magocracy, the wizards created the boot grabber and other foul creatures, before ultimately spawning the first gibbering mouther.

entries.name: Shadow Dwellers
entries: Boot grabbers are usually encountered in underground locations on the Material Plane, but they also inhabit the Plane of Shadow, where they are sometimes used by shadow fey nobles as guardians in the tunnels beneath their castles. On both planes, boot grabbers can often be found working in tandem with the alien-looking darkmantles, hunting together and sharing the spoils. These partnerships prove very effective-the darkmantle's darkness aura conceals both creatures' presence, and a target held fast by the boot grabber can readily be engulfed by the darkmantle.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The chupacabra has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Running Leap
entries: With a 10-foot running start, the chupacabra can long jump up to 25 feet.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the chupacabra attaches to the target. While attached, the chupacabra doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the chupacabra's turns, the target loses 6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) hp due to blood loss. The chupacabra can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after the target is reduced to 0 hp. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the chupacabra.

action.name: Fearful Gaze
entries: The chupacabra fixes its gaze on one creature it can see within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. A {@condition paralyzed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the chupacabra's Fearful Gaze for the next 24 hours.

reaction.name: Malodorous Stench
entries: When the chupacabra is reduced to less than half of its maximum hp, it releases a foul, sulphurous stench. Each creature within 5 feet of the chupacabra must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

{@i This fearsome creature stands about three feet tall and looks like a cross between a dog and a reptile. Its body is covered in a leathery greenish-gray hide, and a crest of spines runs down its back. A pair of bulging, glowing eyes stare intently as it opens its mouth, revealing a set of razor sharp fangs.}

Chupacabras wander remote hills and plains at night, alone or in small packs, in search of their prey. They will sometimes attack lone humans, but they prefer to feed on the blood of sheep and other domestic animals. Goats are a particular favorite.

entries.name: Stealthy Hunters
entries: The chupacabra stalks its quarry before leaping out and sinking its teeth into the creature's neck to drain its blood. When hunting in open ground, the chupacabra will use its terrible glowing eyes to paralyze its victim with fear before attacking. Creatures killed by chupacabra are found completely drained of blood with a triangular, almost bat-shaped, puncture wound in their necks. Superstitious farmers may blame vampires, but those brave enough, and who know of the chupacabra, may band together to hunt down the true culprit, using a caged goat as bait.

entries.name: Servants of the Demon Bat
entries: Chupacabras are sometimes bred underground by derro worshippers of {@creature Camazotz, Demon Lord of Bats and Fire|ToB|Camazotz}, the Demon Lord of Bats ({@loader Tome of Beasts|creature/Kobold Press; Tome of Beasts.json}). The sudden appearance of the creatures in a locality may indicate the presence of Demon Bat cultists below ground. Worse, whispered rumors tell of chupacabras with bat-like wings created by the derro savants under direction from their dreaded {@creature Mi-Go|ToB} allies.

trait.name: Healed By Blood
entries: Whenever a creature is reduced to 0 hp within 60 feet of the execrable shrub, the shrub regains 5 ({@dice 1d10}) hp.

trait.name: Like Calls to Like
entries: The execrable shrub knows if a creature within 60 feet of it is evil-aligned or not.

trait.name: Limited Telepathy
entries: Using telepathy, the execrable shrub can magically communicate with any other evil-aligned creature within 100 feet of it. This communication is primarily through images and emotions rather than actual words.

action.name: Burning Slash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage plus 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage.

action.name: Smolder {@recharge 5}
entries: The execrable shrub releases a billowing cloud of smoke in a 10-foot-radius that lasts for 1 minute and moves with the shrub. The area affected by the smoke is heavily obscured.

{This crimson shrub is covered in brilliant, red thorns and mottled, blood-colored foliage. Small white flowers bloom on its branches before rapidly turning into stone hard fruit. Smoke rises from its leaves, and the ground where it grows is hot to the touch.}

The shrub is sentient and cunning. Evil creatures find they are welcomed into its thorny mass without impediment, and the shrub is grown as a perimeter defense for fiendish strongholds. Hunger and its callous nature prevent it from being a reliable ally, and the creatures who believe they control the execrable shrub often wind up feeding its thirst for blood.

entries.name: Nurturers of Evil
entries: The execrable shrub offers shelter and protection to all manner of foul things. The plant typically grows around old ruins or caverns to tempt monstrous creatures to lair there. So long as the shrub has a steady supply of blood and meat, the relationship between plant and inhabitant remains agreeable.

entries.name: Resentful
entries: The execrable shrub is the lowest form of fiendish plant. For this reason, it is often abused and slaughtered to feed the more advanced forms. This makes the shrub distrustful of other fiendish plants, and, though it will obey the stronger varieties, it secretly plots to usurp them. In combat, the shrub might seize on an opportunity to feed on a wounded ally.

trait.name: Keen Senses
entries: The foxin has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

trait.name: Neutral Presence
entries: A foxin naturally emits an air of total belonging. It doesn't go unnoticed, but other creatures always behave as though the foxin's presence is normal and unobtrusive.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Illusory Calm
entries: The foxin targets any number of non-foxin creatures within 30 feet. Each creature in that area must succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be treated as {@condition charmed} against all enemies and dangers for 1 minute. A {@condition charmed} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the foxin's Illusory Calm for the next 24 hours. A creature has advantage on the saving throw if it suffers any harm while {@condition charmed}.
{@i A long-eared fox-like fey creature sits serenely, its fur the color of morning's first light.}
Foxin come in a myriad of vibrant colors. Sometimes referred to as "the morning calm," they cause an unnatural sense of false tranquility.

entries.name: Serene Purpose
entries: Foxin were originally created by a benevolent fey as a companion to healers. A foxin's natural aura can remove pain, fear, and discomfort, providing a pleasant illusion to those hurt or dying.

entries.name: Problematic Power
entries: The foxin's natural calming ability erases any perception of danger or harm. One could be attacked or imperiled in a foxin's presence and remain blissfully unaware, smiling contentedly until it was too late.

entries.name: Potential Misuse
entries: An army with a foxin as an ally could decimate its enemies without resistance. Happily, foxin are difficult to convince to participate in such atrocities. Their desires are individual and unpredictable. Their motives are often inscrutable; they manifest their powers at random or for their own amusement.

monster.name: Goat-Knight Steed
languages: understands Dwarvish but can't speak it

images.title: Art Credit: {@link Ilich Henriquez|http://deviantart.com/ilacha}
images.altText: A dwarf with long, braided brown beard and clad in full plate armor, sits atop a large, wiry-haired mountain goat.

trait.name: Shared Spells
entries: Any spell the {@creature Kraghammer Goat-Knight|TDCSR|goat-knight} casts with a range of self also targets the goat-knight steed .

trait.name: Summoned Nature
entries: When a goat-knight steed drops to 0 hit points, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form. The {@creature Kraghammer Goat-Knight|TDCSR|goat-knight} can also dismiss the steed at any time as an action, causing it to disappear. In either case, the same steed is summoned when the {@creature Kraghammer Goat-Knight|TDCSR|goat-knight} casts {@spell find steed}.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the goat-knight steed moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target and then hits it with a ram attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 5 ({@damage 2d4}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Sure-Footed
entries: The goat-knight steed has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it {@condition prone}.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

trait.name: Angelic Awareness
entries: The chamrosh has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks to determine if a creature is lying or if a creature has an evil alignment.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The chamrosh doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks} when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The chamrosh has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fearsome Bark {@recharge 5}
entries: The chamrosh lets out a high-pitched bark at a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target is of evil alignment, it must make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage and is {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn. On a success, the target takes half the damage and isn't {@condition frightened}. The bark has no effect on neutral or good-aligned creatures.

action.name: Healing Lick (2/Day)
entries: The chamrosh licks another creature. The target magically regains 10 ({@damage 2d8 + 1}) hp and is cured of the {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, and {@condition poisoned} conditions.
This large sheepdog has luxuriant white-gold fur. A pair of broad wings stretches out from the creature's back, and its eyes are filled with an intelligent, silvery gleam.

entries.name: Celestial Guard Dogs
entries: Created from the souls of exceptionally faithful guards and retainers who selflessly sacrificed themselves to protect others, chamrosh are celestials that take the form of large sheepdogs with silver-gold fur and eagle-like wings. They are known for their ability to sniff out evil and for their steadfast nature, refusing to back down from a fight even in the face of overwhelming odds. Because of this quality, chamrosh are often used as guard beasts by other celestials, though they are never treated as simple pets by even the haughtiest of angels.

entries.name: Roaming Defenders
entries: When not employed by more powerful celestials as companions and guards, chamrosh gather in small packs to roam the planes of good, attacking any fiend or evil monster they come across. They also rescue lost or trapped mortals of good or neutral alignment, leading the mortals to a place of safety or to the nearest portal back to the Material Plane. Despite their appearance, chamrosh can speak and readily do so with mortals they rescue or celestials they serve or protect...

entries.name: Occasional Planar Travelers
entries: Chamrosh rarely travel to the Material Plane, but when they do, it is usually for an important mission, such as to defend a holy relic or to aid a paladin on a divine quest. Since a chamrosh cannot change its form, such missions do not generally involve infiltration or deception, and when the task is finished, the chamrosh is quick to return to its normal duties.

trait.name: Erratic Discharge
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the balloon spider must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage and can move or take an action on its turn, but not both. On a success, the creature gains the benefits of the {@spell haste} spell until the end of its turn. If a creature's saving throw is successful, it is immune to the spider's Erratic Discharge for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or it can move or take an action on its turn, but not both.

action.name: Charged Web {@recharge 4}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +5} to hit, range 40/80 ft., one target. {@h}The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 13}) by strands of charged webbing and begins to hover off the ground. Until this grapple ends, the target takes 1 lightning damage at the start of each of its turns. In addition, the {@condition grappled} target can make a {@dc 12} Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check to manipulate the strands of webbing and fly 10 feet in any direction.

action.name: Draw In
entries: The balloon spider magically pulls all creatures {@condition grappled} by its webbing up to 10 feet toward it. If this movement pulls the creature within 5 feet of the balloon spider, the spider can make one bite attack against the creature as a bonus action.

Honed by evolutionary processes, the balloon spider has perfected the art of ballooning, floating through the air held aloft by strands of webbing suspended by electromagnetic fields. Electrified mandibles grant these spiders precise control over nearby electromagnetic fields and a potent weapon for shocking its prey.

Beneath their hunting grounds, the corpses and bones of their prey lie sparsely coated with stray strands of blue webbing. These remains wobble and glide across the ground of their own accord, caught in stray eddies in the electromagnetic field. The webbing of a balloon spider is prized by arcanists as a component for spells and the construction of magical flying machines.

trait.name: Gem Illumination
entries: As a bonus action, the carbuncle can cause its garnet to glow or not. While glowing, the garnet sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet.

trait.name: Jungle Camouflage
entries: The carbuncle has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in jungle terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The carbuncle makes one bite attack and one claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage.

action.name: Light Beam {@recharge 5}
entries: The carbuncle shoots a 30-foot-long, 5-foot-wide line of scintillating light from the garnet on its forehead. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
